EDITORIAL COMMENT
THE BARNSTORMERS PRESENT
EPORTS, which emanate from the sanctum sanctorum of the
Barnstormers' Club, indicate that "Pop" Swindell, the jovial
coach of the undergraduate dramatic organization, has another successful production up his sleeve and ready for the approval of the
student body. The final nail has been hammered into the framework of the scenery, the last brushful of paint has been slapped on
the back-drop, and the actors are perfecting their lines and "business"
for the dress rehearsal. Everything is in readiass for the rise of the
curtain at the Lyric: Theatre on Thursday evening.
Having depicted the trials and tribulations of an aristocratic
pugilist, the campus mimes now turn their attention to one of those
mythical kingdom extravaganzas, so dear to the heart of Richard
Harding Davis or the late George Barr McCutcheon. This year,
the Barnstormers will dramatize the adventures of one -Anthony
Hamilton Hawthorne of.the United States of America. .Jack Deets,
in the title role, will be given an opportunity to romp among the
prime ministers, emperors, chancellors and army officers of the famous principality of Borrovina. Although this empire does not
appear on the maps, published in standard atlases, the author vouches
for the fact that it is located somewhere in southeastern Europe.
In this Balkan state, the Barnstormers will portray the crafty diplomacy of bewhiskered councilors of state, turbulent love scenes in
the palace garden and other ingredients of melodrama, romance and
mystery which will certainly make the production another sure-fire
•
success.
Evei since their organization, the Barnstormers have formed the
annoying habit of consistently staging successful shows. Old alumni
never cease talking of the 'Stormers' productions of The Purple Mask
and The Galloper. Present undergraduates recall pleasant memories
of Evans Rodgers' splendid portrayal of the pants pressing hero
in The Tailor Made Man; Alger Hiss' capable characterization of
the archeological fanatic in His Majesty Bunker Bean and Benny
Boynton's fine acting as a potential jack Dempsey in last year's production, The Champion.
Baltimore's dramatic critics, notoriously harsh in their condemnation of plays on the legitimate stage, have always hastened to
drape laurel wreaths on the.-perspiring brows of the campus actors.
Year after year, the 13ornstorrnerlhows receive careful coaching
and directing from Mr, Swindell and the results of his efforts are
always evident in the finished production. The undergraduate Barrymores play their roles with the technique of professional players.
Ther7awkward, motions and mumbled lines, so characteristic of the
average amateur actor, are entirely replaced by polished stage presence and clear cut enunciation. In place of the shoddy, dilapidated
scenery provided for the typical non-professional show, the Barnstormers construct stage sets which would do credit to the studio
of any Broadway scenic designer.
Neither have the Barnstormers fallen into the errors of many
other college dramatic groups, who are attempting, with little or no
success, to steal the Theatre Guild's glory. While the Goucher girls
dabble with the intricacies of Bernard Shaw's Caesar and Cleopatra,
the Hopkins boys are content to play Mr. Fagan's melodramatic work
which is so suited to the youthful exuberance of the average undergraduate actor. While other college theatrical organizations stumble
up the Parnassian heights with Eugene O'Neil, Ibsen and Strindberg, the Barnstormers are willing to produce light dramatic fare
The Hopkins group subscribes to the sensible theory that it is far
better to present light farce in an entertaining fashion than to desecrate the masterpieces of the geniuses of our modern theatre by
giving them an inadequate production.
When the final curtain comes rustling down on the last scene
of Hawthorne of the U. S. A., we feel certain that the usual tumultuous applatir from the audience will herald still another Barnstormer success. After all, it is hard to overcome the habit of succeeding.

The Mines Field Illumination
Where do young college men get in a
large industrial organization? Have
they opportunity to exercise creative
talent? Is individual work recognized?
f

1'

f

FIELD,Los Angeles,
is famous as the scene of
the 19213 International Air Races
and Aeronautical Exposition.
Equally famous among flyers is
the perfect illumination which
enabled pilots on the night programs to land with all the ease
and assurance of
those who did their
flying there by day.

M

IN ES

To blanket the field with
brilliance and yet avoid dangerous
glare was the problem assigned to
the Westinghouse engineers who
designed the Mines Field lighting
for this greatest of air meets.
Twenty-one huge floodlight projectors, each with a maximum
beam candlepower of one million,
provided the brilliance. An ingenious system of louvres cutting
off upward rays of light provided
protection from glare at all times.

The result was an achievement
in.airport lighting which has
been pronounced the most nearly
perfect of any in the United
States.
The outstanding jobs go to
organizations with the resources
and facilities to handle them.
Westinghouse, because of the outstanding opportunities which are
of almost daily occurrence within
its organization, offers strong attractions to young men of enterprise and ability who
are anxious to make
a mark in the world.

EDITORIAL COMMENT
THE BARNSTORMERS PRESENT
EPORTS, which emanate from the sanctum sanctorum of the
Barnstormers' Club, indicate that "Pop" Swindell, the jovial
coach of the undergraduate dramatic organization, has another successful production up his sleeve and ready for the approval of the
student body. The final nail has been hammered into the framework of the scenery, the last brushful of paint has been slapped on
the back-drop, and the actors are perfecting their lines and "business"
for the dress rehearsal. Everything is in readiass for the rise of the
curtain at the Lyric: Theatre on Thursday evening.
Having depicted the trials and tribulations of an aristocratic
pugilist, the campus mimes now turn their attention to one of those
mythical kingdom extravaganzas, so dear to the heart of Richard
Harding Davis or the late George Barr McCutcheon. This year,
the Barnstormers will dramatize the adventures of one -Anthony
Hamilton Hawthorne of.the United States of America. .Jack Deets,
in the title role, will be given an opportunity to romp among the
prime ministers, emperors, chancellors and army officers of the famous principality of Borrovina. Although this empire does not
appear on the maps, published in standard atlases, the author vouches
for the fact that it is located somewhere in southeastern Europe.
In this Balkan state, the Barnstormers will portray the crafty diplomacy of bewhiskered councilors of state, turbulent love scenes in
the palace garden and other ingredients of melodrama, romance and
mystery which will certainly make the production another sure-fire
•
success.
Evei since their organization, the Barnstormers have formed the
annoying habit of consistently staging successful shows. Old alumni
never cease talking of the 'Stormers' productions of The Purple Mask
and The Galloper. Present undergraduates recall pleasant memories
of Evans Rodgers' splendid portrayal of the pants pressing hero
in The Tailor Made Man; Alger Hiss' capable characterization of
the archeological fanatic in His Majesty Bunker Bean and Benny
Boynton's fine acting as a potential jack Dempsey in last year's production, The Champion.
Baltimore's dramatic critics, notoriously harsh in their condemnation of plays on the legitimate stage, have always hastened to
drape laurel wreaths on the.-perspiring brows of the campus actors.
Year after year, the 13ornstorrnerlhows receive careful coaching
and directing from Mr, Swindell and the results of his efforts are
always evident in the finished production. The undergraduate Barrymores play their roles with the technique of professional players.
Ther7awkward, motions and mumbled lines, so characteristic of the
average amateur actor, are entirely replaced by polished stage presence and clear cut enunciation. In place of the shoddy, dilapidated
scenery provided for the typical non-professional show, the Barnstormers construct stage sets which would do credit to the studio
of any Broadway scenic designer.
Neither have the Barnstormers fallen into the errors of many
other college dramatic groups, who are attempting, with little or no
success, to steal the Theatre Guild's glory. While the Goucher girls
dabble with the intricacies of Bernard Shaw's Caesar and Cleopatra,
the Hopkins boys are content to play Mr. Fagan's melodramatic work
which is so suited to the youthful exuberance of the average undergraduate actor. While other college theatrical organizations stumble
up the Parnassian heights with Eugene O'Neil, Ibsen and Strindberg, the Barnstormers are willing to produce light dramatic fare
The Hopkins group subscribes to the sensible theory that it is far
better to present light farce in an entertaining fashion than to desecrate the masterpieces of the geniuses of our modern theatre by
giving them an inadequate production.
When the final curtain comes rustling down on the last scene
of Hawthorne of the U. S. A., we feel certain that the usual tumultuous applatir from the audience will herald still another Barnstormer success. After all, it is hard to overcome the habit of succeeding.

The Mines Field Illumination
Where do young college men get in a
large industrial organization? Have
they opportunity to exercise creative
talent? Is individual work recognized?
f

1'

f

FIELD,Los Angeles,
is famous as the scene of
the 19213 International Air Races
and Aeronautical Exposition.
Equally famous among flyers is
the perfect illumination which
enabled pilots on the night programs to land with all the ease
and assurance of
those who did their
flying there by day.

M

IN ES

To blanket the field with
brilliance and yet avoid dangerous
glare was the problem assigned to
the Westinghouse engineers who
designed the Mines Field lighting
for this greatest of air meets.
Twenty-one huge floodlight projectors, each with a maximum
beam candlepower of one million,
provided the brilliance. An ingenious system of louvres cutting
off upward rays of light provided
protection from glare at all times.

The result was an achievement
in.airport lighting which has
been pronounced the most nearly
perfect of any in the United
States.
The outstanding jobs go to
organizations with the resources
and facilities to handle them.
Westinghouse, because of the outstanding opportunities which are
of almost daily occurrence within
its organization, offers strong attractions to young men of enterprise and ability who
are anxious to make
a mark in the world.

Westinghouse

be tight. On details such as that hung
the attainment of the day's goal and the final
success of the expedition.
Lewis and Clark, first Americans to cross
the continent, knew the importance of
"trifles" in the concerted plan. They saw to
it their equipment was right, they supervised
every step from man-power to pack-horse-

constant vigilance to their task.
Today's leaders in business have the same
point of view.

country, take ififinite pains in preparation.

of engineering, manufacturing, warehousing,

profitably or even safely locked up in a safe deposit box and forgotten.

cause variations in the underlying and market values of investment.
Therefore, in order to avoid a possiblo reduction of principal or income, and to take advantage of opportunIties for profit, it Is vitally

the general and particular factors which may affect the investment
